PRICE, FIVE CENTS
JUNIORS REMAIN FIRM
Hold to Former Offer to Seniors for
Joint Annual and Arrange for
Hopkins' Night

Another effort to bring about a
reconciliation between the junior
and senior classes relative to the
publication of the Hullabaloo was
made at a meeting of the juniors
on Tuesday of last week. The
meeting was called to consider
holding a benefit at .one of the
theatres for the ,purpose of raising
money for the annual, but the question of possible-..rivalry with the
seniors soon arose, and much of
the time waS devoted to discussing
the rejection of the juniors' plan
for a joint • Hullaba,loo by the upper
class.
.
A Motion. was finally passed authorizing -the HullabaloO Bbard,and
the committee appointed 'to look
after the financing of .the book
to arrange any agreement their
thought fit with the seniors; but it
was understood that the original
proposition Of the class would be
adhered to.
After much discussion of the proposed benefit, the choice of the
show and the terms were also, left
to the Hullabaloo Board, and the
committee to arrange. Several
propositions from theatrical managers were laid before the meeting
by Manager'Belt.
Mr. William Harrison, formerly
of the class of 1911, whose absence
from the University last year made
it necessary for him to enter the
junior classes this session, was
unanimously elected a member of
the class.
Following the class meeting, the
Hullabaloo Board and the Finance
Committee held a meeting, at which
the questi-m of a benefit was taken
up at length, and it was decided
to accept the offer of the opening
night of the "Arcadians" at the
Academy, for Hopkins' night. . Arrangements are now in progress
for making this the biggest occasion of its kind in years, and it
is hoped that all classes will help
to sell the tickets and make the
Hullabaloo possible.

As THE NEWS-LETTER goes to
press it can be definitely announced
that the St. Johns game will positively be played on Saturday.
Manager Haynes deserves L the
hearty congratulation of all who
are interested in the contest, for
the self-sacrificing energy he has
shown throughout the season and
especially in meeting this last
emergency in such a successful
manner.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOV. 7, 1910.

The last week before the St.
Johns game has come, and final
preparations are in order. The
main thing is to have the team in
shape to win. Coaches and players
must do their best, and every one
can lest assured that they will, but
they will also need the help of the
student body to make their efforts
a complete success. Scrubs and
rooters should make special efforts
to get to the practices this week,
the former to give the varsity players the best possible scrimmages
for practice, and the latter to put
the ginger into the team that only
the feeling of having an enthusiastic crowd of supporters can give.
However busy anyone may be, this
is the time of all times to get out
and hustle for the football team,
even at some sacrifice of personal
interests and pleasures.
The success of the Hopkins team
against the Carlyle Indians will
largely determine the class in which
the University will be ranked as
regards athletics in future years,
and the importance of the games
that future managers will feel justified in arranging. Nothing will go
so far toward inspiring the team
to prove that it is worthy of firstclass opponents when it meets the
Indians next week as a rousing victory over St. Johns. The nature
of the spirit that is shown during
the coming week will be a big factor in settling the athletic future
of Hopkins.
The present system of arranging
the intercollegiate debates is in need
of improvement. The committee
with whom the matter rests is composed each year of members who
are new to the work, unless by
chance one who has served before
is reappointed. The desirability of
having at least a good part of the
committee composed of experienced
students is apparent, but this can

hardly be accomplished so long as
the representation of each class is

While so many lighting experts
are at the University, why not have
some of them see if better light
cannot be secured in the cage? The
lacrosse men complain that the
present installation does not give
them enough light for effective
practice, and it is said that the
runners sometimes have difficulty
in finding the track in the gloom.
And while they are about it, we
hope that these experts will remedy
the trouble with the arc lamps in
the physics lecture room, so that
Professor Ames will no longer have
to choose between speaking against
a steady pounding from the upper
regions and giving his lectures in
total darkness.

Elect Officers and make Rules for the
Year—Purpose and Nature of
the Club

On Friday, October 28, a meeting was held in Levering Hall for
the purpose of organizing a chess
club. It was decided that only
two officers would be necessary.
The officers elected were:
Mr. G. C. Ober, Jr., president.
Mr. Taylor Starck, secretary and
treasurer.
An executive committee, consisting of the two officers, ex-officio,
and Mr. Charles Leland Getz, appointed by the president, will attend
to all minor matters attendant upon
the conduct of the society.
The dues determined upon were
twenty-five cents every two months,
making one dollar for the entire
year. Membership cards will be
issued on the payment of dues. No
one will be entitled to use a chess
set belonging to he society without
first producing his membership
card.
It is not • intended that membership in the club be restricted to
those who have a previous knowledge of the game. On, the con- trary, the main purpose of the organization is to foster a wholesome
interest in chess, and to enable
members to learn something about
it. Later in the year a tournament
will be held, and men selected to
represent the club in matches with
other schools and colleges.
Preparations Rouse Interest

Considerable interest was aroused
and much curiosity shown during
the latter part of last week, as a
result of the elaborate preparations
being made for the meeting of the
American Association for Study
and Prevention of Infant Mortality,
which begins on Wednesday in
McCoy Hall.
As Walter put it:
"Dey's gettin' ready fo' a big
baby show upstairs and I'll be
blessed ef dey ain't jes' natchelly
tu'ned de whole place upside
down !"
The presence on the program of
the names of such distinguished
scholars and philanthropists as M.
Jusserand, Dr. Wm. H. Welch,
and Prof. Irving Fisher, of Yale,
makes certain a large attendance
at the meetings of the Association,
while the prominence in its work
of a number of Hopkins alumni
and professors, together with the
elaborate educational display that
has been prepared in McCoy Hall,
assures the deepest interest in the
sessions of the body throughout
the University. The complete program of the meetings will be found
in last week's issue of THE NEWS-

THE NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 7, 1910
College Life Elsewhere.

The following interesting occurrence happened at one of our
northern colleges last year:
One of the customs there is to
have in the early fall a tug-of-war
between the freshmen and sophomores. This contest takes place at
a small pond, the two classes standing on the opposite banks. In order
to win, the one side must pull the
other through the pond. The
Penalty for defeat is that a green
skull cap must be worn by every
member of the losing class from
the date of the contest until Easter.
Last year the freshmen were the
losers. But the freshmen had previously made the president of the
college an honorary member of
their class. So when the green
skull caps were being distributed
among the freshmen by the sophomores, in a spirit of mischief they
sent one to the president also.
Some of the more timid members
of the class expected a severe reprimand. But the president showed
his ability to fall in with the joke
and from that day forward until
Easter he wore his green skull cap
whenever he appeared on the
campus.
Lacrosse Schedule.

Announcement was made last
Friday by Manager Herbert P.
Makel of the Hopkins lacrosse team
of the schedule for the coming season. All but two of the dates are
filled and the character of the teams
taken on is sufficient to refute any
notion that Hopkins is declining in
the lacrosse world.
The unfilled dates will be taken
on by Cornell and Carlisle if negotiations now in progress are successful.

THE NEWS-LETTER,

Batlintorc, Md.
Dear Sir—As an alumnus, I want
to tell you how your efforts to make
THE NEWS-LETTER worth while are
appreciated.
It should prove a very pleasant
means to keep us in touch with
the University work and sports,
and we look forward to its weekly
appearance with a great deal of
pleasure.
• I should like to see a few more
alumni notes so that we might follow a little more closely the personal doings of our former classmates. Very sincerely yours,
J. R. B. BRANCH, A. B.'04;
M.D., '08,
Supt. Macon Hospital.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOV. 7, 1910.

The last week before the St.
Johns game has come, and final
preparations are in order. The
main thing is to have the team in
shape to win. Coaches and players
must do their best, and every one
can lest assured that they will, but
they will also need the help of the
student body to make their efforts
a complete success. Scrubs and
rooters should make special efforts
to get to the practices this week,
the former to give the varsity players the best possible scrimmages
for practice, and the latter to put
the ginger into the team that only
the feeling of having an enthusiastic crowd of supporters can give.
However busy anyone may be, this
is the time of all times to get out
and hustle for the football team,
even at some sacrifice of personal
interests and pleasures.
The success of the Hopkins team
against the Carlyle Indians will
largely determine the class in which
the University will be ranked as
regards athletics in future years,
and the importance of the games
that future managers will feel justified in arranging. Nothing will go
so far toward inspiring the team
to prove that it is worthy of firstclass opponents when it meets the
Indians next week as a rousing victory over St. Johns. The nature
of the spirit that is shown during
the coming week will be a big factor in settling the athletic future
of Hopkins.
The present system of arranging
the intercollegiate debates is in need
of improvement. The committee
with whom the matter rests is composed each year of members who
are new to the work, unless by
chance one who has served before
is reappointed. The desirability of
having at least a good part of the
committee composed of experienced
students is apparent, but this can

Elect Officers and make Rules for the
Year—Purpose and Nature of
the Club

On Friday, October 28, a meeting was held in Levering Hall for
the purpose of organizing a chess
club. It was decided that only
two officers would be necessary.
The officers elected were:
Mr. G. C. Ober, Jr., president.
Mr. Taylor Starck, secretary and
treasurer.
An executive committee, consisting of the two officers, ex-officio,
and Mr. Charles Leland Getz, appointed by the president, will attend
to all minor matters attendant upon
the conduct of the society.
The dues determined upon were
twenty-five cents every two months,
making one dollar for the entire
year. Membership cards will be
issued on the payment of dues. No
one will be entitled to use a chess
set belonging to he society without
first producing his membership
card.
It is not • intended that membership in the club be restricted to
those who have a previous knowledge of the game. On, the con- trary, the main purpose of the organization is to foster a wholesome
interest in chess, and to enable
members to learn something about
it. Later in the year a tournament
will be held, and men selected to
represent the club in matches with
other schools and colleges.
Preparations Rouse Interest

Considerable interest was aroused
and much curiosity shown during
the latter part of last week, as a
result of the elaborate preparations
being made for the meeting of the
American Association for Study
and Prevention of Infant Mortality,
which begins on Wednesday in
McCoy Hall.
As Walter put it:
"Dey's gettin' ready fo' a big
baby show upstairs and I'll be
blessed ef dey ain't jes' natchelly
tu'ned de whole place upside
down !"
The presence on the program of
the names of such distinguished
scholars and philanthropists as M.
Jusserand, Dr. Wm. H. Welch,
and Prof. Irving Fisher, of Yale,
makes certain a large attendance
at the meetings of the Association,
while the prominence in its work
of a number of Hopkins alumni
and professors, together with the
elaborate educational display that
has been prepared in McCoy Hall,
assures the deepest interest in the
sessions of the body throughout
the University. The complete program of the meetings will be found
in last week's issue of THE NEWS-

THE NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 7, 1910
College Life Elsewhere.

The following interesting occurrence happened at one of our
northern colleges last year:
One of the customs there is to
have in the early fall a tug-of-war
between the freshmen and sophomores. This contest takes place at
a small pond, the two classes standing on the opposite banks. In order
to win, the one side must pull the
other through the pond. The
Penalty for defeat is that a green
skull cap must be worn by every
member of the losing class from
the date of the contest until Easter.
Last year the freshmen were the
losers. But the freshmen had previously made the president of the
college an honorary member of
their class. So when the green
skull caps were being distributed
among the freshmen by the sophomores, in a spirit of mischief they
sent one to the president also.
Some of the more timid members
of the class expected a severe reprimand. But the president showed
his ability to fall in with the joke
and from that day forward until
Easter he wore his green skull cap
whenever he appeared on the
campus.
Lacrosse Schedule.

Announcement was made last
Friday by Manager Herbert P.
Makel of the Hopkins lacrosse team
of the schedule for the coming season. All but two of the dates are
filled and the character of the teams
taken on is sufficient to refute any
notion that Hopkins is declining in
the lacrosse world.
The unfilled dates will be taken
on by Cornell and Carlisle if negotiations now in progress are successful.
The schedule is as follows:
March 25—Columbia University.
\!arch 30—Navy.
April 1—Alumni.
April 8—Pending.
April 15—Harvard.
April 22—Pending.
April 29—Swarthmore.
May 6—Lehigh.
May 13—Stevens.

THE NEWS-LETTER,

Batlintorc, Md.
Dear Sir—As an alumnus, I want
to tell you how your efforts to make
THE NEWS-LETTER worth while are
appreciated.
It should prove a very pleasant
means to keep us in touch with
the University work and sports,
and we look forward to its weekly
appearance with a great deal of
pleasure.
• I should like to see a few more
alumni notes so that we might follow a little more closely the personal doings of our former classmates. Very sincerely yours,
J. R. B. BRANCH, A. B.'04;
M.D., '08,
Supt. Macon Hospital.
